review.title: Social Media Text Processing and Semantic Analysis for Smart Cities
review.abstract: With the rise of Social Media, people obtain and share information almost instantly on a 24/7 basis. Many research areas have tried to gain valuable insights from these large volumes of freely available user generated content.

sections.heading: 1.1 Scope and Motivation
sections.text: With the rise of social media, people are receiving and sharing information almost immediately on a 24 / 7 basis. Many research fields have tried to extract valuable insights from these large amounts of user-generated content. The research fields of intelligent transportation systems and smart cities are no exception. Converting this data into valuable information can be useful and useful for city management, supporting traffic management and control, transportation services or even ordinary citizens want to be constantly informed about their cities. For example, if a social media message is about the quality of bus service - "My bus is delayed." - then the responsible companies should have the tools and information necessary to address the existing problem. However, in order to extract the knowledge to master the solution task, it is necessary first to filter travel-relevant messages from unrelated areas and then to explore the topic, feeling or even the goal of its contents. Social media content (SMC) is still in the process of maturing in relation to its GM12 + users tending to participate in the Smart AG and GT14 events they have in public [GT14].

sections.heading: 1.2 Problem Statement
sections.text: "The problem of the lack of gold standards is not the way in which we link the most relevant topics, events, or even interests in particular places." The problem of the lack of gold standards is not the way in which we collect the most relevant information in each country, but the way in which we process this information. "We," the communication says, "are the most important information we have in each country." The informal language, the existence of slang, abbreviations, jargons, and the short length of the message are some of the problems that arise in analyzing this data and are time consuming. "The task is even more complex, the existence of slang, abbreviations, jargons, and the short length of the message are some of the problems that tweets automatically analyze, while extracting valuable information for smart cities and transport domains. Geo-localized tweets can make the task even more complex" for tweets to play a fundamental role, as the study of their content can be characterized, the topics can be associated with specific interests, or even specific interests.

sections.heading: 1.3 Aim and Goals
sections.text: This work aims to design and develop a research framework for word processing and semantic analysis of geo-localized tweets within a predefined geographical area (e.g. cities). To put such a framework into practice, we will achieve the following objectives: • Continuous collection of geo-localized tweets from multiple Bounding Boxes in parallel and in accordance with the usage limits of the Twitter API; • Elimination of Twitter Geo API inconsistencies and filtering of loud tweets; • Implementation of standard text pre-processing methods for social media texts; • Content analysis using topic modeling and comparative characterization between different Bounding Boxes (e.g. cities); • Travel-related classification of tweets using supervised learning; • Train Word Embedings from geo-localized tweets; • Investigation of the impact of word embedding in travel-related classifications; • Creation of gold standard data for travel-related learning; • Aggregation and visualization of results.

sections.heading: 1.4 Document Structure
sections.text: The rest of this document is broken down as follows: Chapter 2 begins with a brief contextualization of Smart Cities and ITS, as well as previous related work based on Social-Media4Introduction Content. The proposed framework is referred to in Chapter 3, detailing each of its compositional modules. Experiments conducted to test each module of the framework are reported in Chapter 5. We finish the document with Chapter 6, which sets out conclusions, future work, and some final comments. 5Introduction 6Chapter 2Background and Literature Review

sections.text: This section aims to analyze and reflect on some works whose ultimate goal, like ours, is to develop a framework for exploring social media data in order to extract meaningful domain-specific information. Nevertheless, studying the works of other authors can help or even find proposed solutions to the problems mentioned above. Therefore, this section will consider a brief contextualization of how an intelligent system can contribute to the improvement of a city or a transportation system. Furthermore, it describes technologies and methods that allow the extraction of information from a text document or, in this particular case, tweets. Finally, it will examine existing frameworks for the extraction of information from social media content and the identification of its scope.

sections.heading: 2.1 Smart Cities
sections.text: In recent years, several definitions of its meaning have emerged, but their main idealization is not yet fully known. [7] Angelidou [8] defined Smart City as a "conceptual urban development model based on the use of people, collectives and technological capital for the development of urban agglomerations." The primary factors that support the development of a city are: in addition to the previous factors, the author identifies other three different forces that shape the concept of a city.

sections.heading: 2.2 Intelligent Transportation Systems
sections.text: Transport systems are inherently linked to the progress of a city because people use transport systems on a daily basis, i.e. they are increasingly affected by the problem of population growth, which is relevant and necessary to find solutions for their jobs and to shape their own lives. Therefore, an intelligent city should focus on its actions to become smarter. "To understand what ITS is, it is necessary to introduce the importance of Smart Mobility (SM). SM is a combination of comprehensive and intelligent transport systems that provide control of traffic volume, times of buses, subways and air routes, their routes and even citizens" knowledge of the city's services.

sections.heading: 2.3 Social Media Analytics
sections.text: In recent years, social networks have made an impact on business communication, as users have assumed the role of customers by publishing content on these networks, with a high level of interaction between them and the companies [USRS16]. Evidence of this is the amount of information produced since 2011, which corresponds to a number of over10Background and Literature Reviewthan 90% of the available data online [SIN13]. Facebook1, Twitter2 and other social networking sites are nowadays used as a business tool by companies that aim at the efficient use of digital marketing techniques to publish their products [RL14b]. In addition to the business field, the population is widely engaged in these new communication technologies to publicly share real events, their opinions on specific topics and their time sensations on the network through a simple message [DDLM15]. Social Media Analytics (SMA) can be described as a type of digital analytics that focuses on the investigation of interactions between companies, providing their opinions on their own products, or the information necessary for their own business.

Several papers have already been proposed to identify social patterns in the daily life of the population and to capture such patterns geographically by topic modeling techniques in order to discover latent topics on social media.

sections.heading: 2.4.2.1 Classification Evaluation Metrics
sections.text: To measure the performance of a text classification model, there are different types of metrics that can support this process, depending on the context of the task, of course. In binary classification tasks, the most common metrics are precision, recall (sensitivity), and F1 score, which is the harmonic mean or weighted mean of the previous two values. • Recall: Represents the proportion of travel-related tweets correctly predicted (Equation 2.2). • Precision = t pt p + f p (2.1) Recall = t p + f n (2.2), where t p is related to the true positive tweets, f p represents the false positive tweets, and f n the false negatives. • Positive score: Represents the harmonic threshold p + f (2.1) Recall = t p + f n (2.2), where t p is related to the true positive tweets, f represents the false scores, f and f are the false negatives.

sections.heading: 2.6 Summary
sections.text: The literature review identifies positive and negative points that need to be reported. First, the conceptualization of a powerful system capable of adding value to the intelligent development of a city is a laborious and time-consuming process. Although iterative steps are necessary, it is the definition of a detailed work plan and what the ultimate goals and objectives of such a system are / are. Crowd sensing is a type of sensor that enables the study of what citizens say on a particular topic, and social media platforms can easily be researched to draw on their content for further analysis and to support the construction of an adaptable and profitable tool for urban entities. Nowadays, text-mining techniques allow the extraction of information from social media content that can be presented on the results after precise aggregations, in visualization views that facilitate analysis by the end users of these systems.

sections.heading: 3.8 Summary . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 33
sections.text: In this chapter, we describe the details and particularities of the framework proposed in this dissertation. First, we set out the requirements necessary to meet and achieve the development mentioned above. In addition, we present the framework architecture design and its internal pipeline. Subsequently, the modules that make up such an architecture are described as the necessary methods and algorithms that are integrated into each of their tasks. Finally, but not least, we mention and explain the various data visualizations that are available within the framework.

sections.heading: 3.1 Requirements
sections.text: The development of frameworks in the areas of smart cities and intelligent transport systems with man-made content (e.g. text messages) is a laborious and time-consuming process. The source of the data that is fed into such a system is one of the biggest challenges in this type of development that reaches from social media, smartphones and urban sensors. In this dissertation, we tackle the problem of researching social media data, as this type of data has lately been seen as a new opportunity and source for the extraction of valuable information to the city services and corresponding responsible entities. Social media data is largely represented by text messages, which are necessary to apply NLP methods to extract information from their contents. Such methods are usually complex 21frame work and consist of several different steps (e.g. related to the syntax of sentences, while others relate to the semantics of their contents) before achieving the desired results. Social media streams are no exception to the fact.

sections.heading: 3.2 Architecture Overview
sections.text: The framework proposed in this dissertation is divided into four different modules: (1) collection and filtering; (2) pre-processing and analysis of text; (3) aggregation and (4) visualization of data.The current collection module is implemented to retrieve tweets from a specific bounding box, but if the user requests, multiple locations can be explored simultaneously.Other collection euristics are also available, such as keyword search and subsequent users. Depending on the target scenario to be examined and the analysis to be examined, these two heuristics must be added to the module. This detail has been taken into account during the implementation period and the flexibility that has been composited into the module. 22FrameworkFiltering tasks are directly related to sites heuristic of the collection module and the analytics to be examined. As this framework is designed to analyze cities or specific regions / zones of the module framework, if other search information from 23rd modules is required, then it will not be implemented.

sections.heading: 3.3 Data Collection
sections.text: In Section 3.1, we explain the importance of the decision made to capture the heuristics of data collection 5,000 prior knowledge about these users within the 24PI box. Twitter allows the developer community two different tools to collect data, the Search and the Streaming Application Programming Interfaces (APIs). The search API is based on Twitter's Representational State Transfer (REST) protocol and searches only for tweets posted in the last 7 days, while the streaming API creates basic endpoints (regardless of the RESTful endpoints) and retrieves up to 1% of Twitter's firehose. With respect to the proposed and developed framework, we chose the streaming API because of its free access to the community, smooth integration into the module implementation and due to the availability of real-time information. A positive point about the streaming API are the three available hayristics for data collection, so the retrieval tweets allow tweets to match with, for example, a text-specific question (the auto-tweet).

sections.heading: 3.3.1 Data Filtering
sections.text: In the first attempts to study the collected data on the geographical distribution of the tweet, we discover that not all tweets contain a precise coordinate attached to them. However, there have been cases where tweets from other cities were collected by our crawler and this phenomenon should not happen if the capture method is based on geo-localized properties. By examining the Twitter application, we have found that a user can mark himself in the tweet in two different ways: (1) a user1https: / / dev.twitter.com / streaming / post / statuses / filter (accessing tweets on 18 / 06 / 2017) 2http: / boundingbox.klokantech.com / (accessing the data on 23 / 06 / 2017) 25Frameworkcan activate the Global Positioning System (GPS) in the mobile application and associate the tweet with its exact geo location; (2) a user can select a location provided by Twitter and associate the tweet with the location.

sections.heading: 3.4 Text Pre-processing
sections.text: In the Requirements section (3.1) we have mentioned some problems of social media streams such as the short length and informality of the text message. • The informality problem extends from the spelling of each person to the existence of many abbreviations, slang, jargons, emoticons and bad use of punctuation marks. • The preprocessing module in this section has as its main objective the submission of the text message among several operations to remove, or at least reduce, this type of informality characteristics and to make the work of future task sketches easier. We enumerate and describe the various preprocessing methods implemented in this section: • Lowercasing: This operation is responsible for the conversion of uppercase to lower representations. The advantages provided by this operation are in the analogous analysis of words that we have written in different ways.

sections.heading: 3.5 Text Analytics
sections.text: The extraction of information from texts may vary in several types depending on the task performed to accomplish it. In this dissertation, we have examined two different types of analysis of tweets: topic modeling and travel-related classification.

sections.heading: 3.5.1 Topic Modelling
sections.text: To extract such information, we implement within our framework a generative module that uses theme modeling techniques.5https: / / pypi.python.org / pypi / pytz28FrameworkTopic modeling is a text-mining technique that aims to identify latent themes in a collection of documents.Over the past decade, the research community has used this technique in a wide range of work aimed at testing their applicability in different areas. Here, we also used theme modeling to characterize different cities and provide this type of information to end-users. Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) is a generative statistical model proposed by D. Blei et al. [BNJ03] that allows the discovery of unknown groups and their similarities in a collection of text documents.The model attempts to identify which themes are present in a document so that a plate observes all 3.DA words.

sections.heading: 3.5.1.1 Features
sections.text: Topic modeling, as in other learning models, requires a group of characteristics that need to be trained. In this case, we used the representation matrix - a representation in which each document is converted into a frequency vector according to the number of occurrences of each word in the message. The feature set was limited to a dictionary of 10,000 words and only took into account unigrams in the message content. The dictionary was also limited to words that occur in a maximum percentage of 40% of the entire data set, avoiding common words that were not removed because they were not included in the NLTK stop word list of the Python for the specific language in the analysis. The minimum occurrence value for a word that is taken into account was set to 10.

sections.heading: 3.5.1.2 LDA Model Resulting Topics
sections.text: The final model used in the implementation of our framework is defined in such a way that it divides a tweet into 50 different topics. Although, in the experiment that was conducted to reduce the added value of the model, we were obliged to group some of the topics based on the similarity presented in the words that make up them, the final list of possible topics can be seen in Section 5.1.1, more precisely Table 5.2.

sections.heading: 3.5.2 Travel-related Classification
sections.text: Prima facie, we tried to extract and characterize travel-related tweets from large datasets in order to study the geographical and temporal distribution of such specific content. Transportation companies can take advantage of this type of information, since human mobility can be studied as well as citizens "opinions about transportation services. The Twitter Streaming API delivers an enormous amount of data, and filtering out the relevant ones in a short time is a tedious process. To succeed in this task, we have developed an automatic text classifier that can distinguish travel-related tweets from non-related ones. As there are no gold standard datasets in this area, a training and testing set of data had to be created to continue the experiment and evaluate the performance of the model produced. Conventional classification tasks in the field of intelligent transportation systems follow traditional approaches by constructing their set of features with standard bag-of-word techniques. In our experiment, we tried to combine a Bog-W with a first-in-line feature.

sections.heading: 3.5.2.1 Features
sections.text: In this group of characteristics we consider only unigrams as the basis of the text representation used by Mikolov et al. [MCCD13] in the implementation of a powerful computational method called word2vec. This method is able to learn distributed representations of words, and each word is represented by a distribution of weights over a fixed number of dimensions. Authors have also proven that such a representation is robust when it encompasses syntactic and semantic similarities in emantic space.

sections.heading: 3.6 Data Storage and Aggregation
sections.text: Apart from the small percentage of geo-localized tweets provided by Twitter (1-2% of the total firehose overcome), this data requires, firstly, a large storage capacity and, secondly, a tool that allows easy manipulation and quick access to data. With this in mind, we decided to use MongoDB, a cross-platform document-oriented open source database, as data warehouse technology for our framework. MongoDB allows the storage of JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) documents, which are the retrieved format of tweets through the Streaming API. Since in this dissertation we developed the framework as a prototype of a system capable of extracting information relating to smart cities and transport services, the large physical storage space for data was not a priority. In addition to the high performance, availability and scaling, MongoDB presents an internal framework that allows us to build the aggregation of data required by the thousands of users, in order to generate such large quantities of statistical specifications.

sections.heading: 3.7 Visualization
sections.text: One of the most complex and time-consuming tasks in the development of this social-media framework is the selection of data visualizations to illustrate the results of the above modules. Visualizing information retrieved from social networks must be easily understandable, and the majority of systems examine important performance indicators, while others use more complex visual representations such as egocentric networks [STSO16]. Due to the amount of data processed, the generation of data visualizations by means of an atomic implementation is sometimes poor in terms of response time. Therefore, we had to take a different approach to solve this inefficient procedure. After a long period of research, we found a solution to this problem by creating a series of routines (Bash scripts) that are called periodically (hourly) to perform all kinds of necessary aggregations and update the corresponding data collections in the database.

sections.heading: 3.8 Summary
sections.text: In this chapter, we will explain the implementation of our framework, the modules it consists of, and the methods and methods chosen for each module concept.During the design and implementation phase, we have tried to maintain modularity throughout the system to allow future extensions or even complementarity of existing modules. The final framework consists of four different interconnected modules. If the situation requires, each module can be adapted to other systems.Finally, we will give an overview of the main features of our framework to end-users information that has been collected, filtered and analyzed in an almost real-time scenario. It is worth noting that due to the tedious tasks that each tweet goes through, it is impossible to provide immediate results as the system should be coherent and not treat each message separately.Information will be made available to end-users in short periods (e.g. 30 minutes), allowing all text modules to provide additional analysis module complementary information to this framework analyse.In this chapter, all additional analysis module tasks are actually available.

sections.heading: 4.4 Summary . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 46
sections.text: The main objective of this chapter is to develop relevant analyses taking into account the five different sets of data collected. As this dissertation is supported in experiments with real-world data, such analysis is crucial in order to gain a better understanding of its inherent characteristics. A tweet provides some areas of interest, such as the text message, the date of creation, the language and the entities that are constantly analyzed in multiple data analysis systems. An entity consists of metadata and additional context information contained in the tweet and is composed of the hashtags, usernames, urls and media fields. We count the number of tweets that contain this type of information for all cities, London, New York, Melbourne, Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo, and project some data visualizations for different temporal frequencies. The following subsections are divided into three different categories: (1) Geographical Distribution, (2) Temporary abundances, and (3) the most important metadata, as well as the differences we discuss.

sections.heading: 4.1 Geographic Distributions
sections.text: As mentioned above, in Section 3.3, we use an additional online tool to generate the coordinates for the out-of-town bouncing boxes used in the collection process; the visual representation of the individual bouncing boxes is illustrated in Figure 4.1, as well as the corresponding tweets in Table 4.1.Taking into account careful observation of the coordinates used within each bouncing box, we can confirm that Rio de Janeiro represents the most comprehensive bouncing box compared to the other cities. 35Exploratory Data AnalysisTo conduct the data filtering process, we extracted from data the Twitter default boundingboxes for each city in study, being possible to observe their corresponding South-West and NorthEast coordinates in Table 4.2. The map visualization of these bouncing boxes is demonstrated in Figures 4.2 (Subfigures 4.2b and 4.2a) and 4.3 (Subfigures 4.3a) and 4.3a (Subfigures 4.3a, Subfigures 4.3c, Subrecta 4.3b and the largest default).

sections.heading: 4.2 Temporal Frequencies
sections.text: Another interesting analysis in our datasets concerns the temporal distribution of the data. The volume of tweets posted per hour, per day, as well as activity by day of the week or hour of the day are statistics that allow the possibility of identifying patterns or variations that can be correlated with some events or incidents that happen in a city. During and after notable events, citizens are encouraged to share their feelings, opinions or even reports on their security and well-being (e.g. in cases of terrorist attacks) through mobile applications. This share of information increases the activity of social media platforms that can potentially be used to identify unusual events. Figure 4.4 illustrates the daily distribution of all cities for the period of recording, three whole months, between 12 March and 12 June 2017. Brazilian cities present a high level of variation between consecutive days (with the volume varying in tens of thousands of tweets), thus performing the task of identifying notable events.

sections.heading: 4.3 Content Composition
sections.text: The metadata contained in a tweet is represented by the hashtags, user mentions, URLs and tweets associated with a user's tweet. Another point to examine is the number of different users who have contributed to the dataset composition. Users whose number of posts is unnatural can sometimes be bots. If there is a time pattern associated with a user's post of tweets, for example, the user posts a tweet in a period of 5 minutes throughout the day, then that user is a potential bot. The existence of bots is not taken into account in this dissertation because the information provided by such an automatic system can also be valuable. In this section, we demonstrated the distribution of users by the number of posts they have made themselves, as well as the counting of the different types of metadata contained in the data.Social media platforms present similar features to each other.

sections.heading: 4.4 Summary
sections.text: In this chapter, we have tried to identify interesting patterns and valuable information that relate only to the simple features that a tweet provides: location, date of creation, and metadata content. Initially, it was possible to identify existing problems related to the capture of geo-localized tweets. In recent years, the research community has proposed many studies that use geo-localized tweets, but to the best of our knowledge, none of them report the problem we have identified in terms of geographical analysis. Our data sets represent only three months of data, as supportive as the analysis may be, we conclude that the majority (> 70%) of tweets are marked with differently sized bouncing boxes instead of precise geo-coordinates. This problem addresses difficult challenges when suggestions from studies on human activity patterns need to be made to our own human mobility 46Exploratory Data Analysisneed in order to use social media content in terms of geo-localized tweets.

sections.heading: 5.1 Topic Modelling . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 49
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.2 Travel-related Classification . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 52
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.3 Summary . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 63
sections.text: In this section, we present two different text analysis experiments on topic modeling and travel-related tweet classification. First, we labeled topics manually to characterize two Brazilian cities, namely Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo. Later, we developed two travel-related classification models to distinguish tweets for two different languages. For both travel-related experiments, we commented manually on an English-language and a Portuguese-language training and test dataset. In the remaining sections, each experiment and the discussion and analysis of the results obtained were described.

sections.heading: 5.1 Topic Modelling
sections.text: In this section, we describe the experiment of automatic characterization of tweets in two different Brazilian cities, Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo. As mentioned in Section 3.5.1, we are using the LDA model to find out what latent topics occur in both cities. We are conducting this experiment on the basis of data collected over a two-month period, from March 12 to May 12, 2017. Following the data filtering and word pre-processing steps, we receive a total of 6.6 million tweets for Rio de Janeiro and 2.7 million tweets for São Paulo. We tried to train the LDA model with 5, 10, 20, 25 and 50 latent topics and manually verified the most likely words for each topic. Models with 5, 10, 20 and 25 showed a high number of overlaps between the topics. Therefore, we opted for the experiment using 50 latents. The number of iterations to train the model was set at 20, in line with the work of Lansley and Text LLley49analytics [L16] experiments.

sections.heading: 5.1.1 Results and Analysis
sections.text: The LDA models offer a semantic label for each theme, such as "Theme x" for sports. "We have checked the most common words of each theme and get assigned a semantic label. Table 5.1 presents the most common words for 5 random themes and the corresponding labels that are manually assigned." Thus, for example, the theme is accompanied by the most common terms such as "gol," "" time, "" "one," "" one, "" "" one, "" "" "," "" "," "" "", "" "" "", "" "" "", "" "" "", "" "" "," "" "", "" "", "" "," "", "", "" "," "," "", "" "," "", "" "," "" "," "" "," "" "," "" "", "" "" "," "" "", "" "", "" "" "," "" "," "" "" "", "" "" "" "," "", "," "" "" "," "" "," "" "," "" "", "" "" "," "" "," "" "", "" "" "", "" "" "" "" "" ",", "", "" "" "" "," "" "" "", "" "," "" "", "" "" "," "" "" ",", "" "," "" "", "" "" "", "" "" "," "", "" ""

sections.heading: 5.1.2 Final Remarks
sections.text: To the best of our knowledge, this is the first large-scale analysis of the topic modeling of geo-localized tweets from Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo. Most of the topics are common to both cities. Interestingly, people in Brazil post geo-localized tweets on general topics, such as reality TV shows, health issues and relationships and friendship. Transportation and travel are marginal topics with a relative frequency of less than 2% in Rio de Janeiro and 2.3% in São Paulo. This experiment demonstrates the ability of our framework to handle different topic modeling analyses under unregulated and unconventional data, as found in most social media. Applying topic modeling techniques to tweets from two different cities allows interesting comparisons between them, as the entire analysis process takes into account what residents are talking about in their social networks. Through this analysis, the services of cities are able to monitor human behavior, activity patterns, and regions where there may be specific issues of intolerance, as there may be preventive measures to address these issues.

sections.heading: 5.2 Travel-related Classification
sections.text: The main objective of this section is to describe the experiments that are being conducted to discriminate tweets related to travel in Rio de Janeiro, São Paulo and New York City. Considering the scope of the 52Text Analytics Experimentscollected data for each scenario, it is necessary to automatically identify tweets whose content somehow suggests being related to the transportation domain. Conventional approaches would require us to classify travel-related keywords in order to classify such tweets. On the contrary, our approach has been to develop a classification model to automatically identify travel-related tweets from unrelated ones.A major challenge that is always present in text analysis is particularly the case in Twitter messages. Conventional techniques such as bag-of-words tend to produce sparse representations that get worse when data are composed by informal and loud contents.d Embedding, on the other hand, is a text representation that attempts to synthesize the technique, and syntactical relationships out of words.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo
sections.text: The messages were collected over a one-month period between March 12 and April 12, 2017, and the resulting records add up to a total of 6.1 million tweets for Rio de Janeiro and 2.9 million tweets for São Paulo. Due to the problem identified in Section 4.1, we filtered the data to use only tweets that were actually within the metropolitan area. The data included in this experiment add up to a total of 7.7 million tweets - 5.3 million tweets and 2.4 million tweets for Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo, respectively.

sections.heading: 5.2.1.1 Training and Test Datasets
sections.text: We tried to build a balanced training set, consisting of 2,000 travel-related tweets and 2,000 non-travel-related tweets. First, we searched tweets using specific travel terms, as described in the study Maghrebi et al. [MAW16]. Table 5.3 shows the terms used to query each travel mode. We found 30,000 tweets that matched these terms. From this subset, we created a layered sample of 3,000 tweets and commented on them manually. In the end, we received 2,000 tweets that were marked as positive (travel-related). To select negative examples, we stamped 2,000 tweets and manually verified whether they were negative (non-travel-related). To create a test set, we randomly selected 1,000 tweets that differed from the training set and then labeled them manually as travel-related or non-travel-travel-related tweets that were not included in the training games.

sections.heading: 5.2.1.2 Results and Analysis
sections.text: Table 5.4 presents the results obtained with the help of the various feature combinations for our test, compiled from 1,000 tweets that were commented manually. By the rating standards, we come to the conclusion that the wordpocket and the embedding pocket combined have produced better tweets. The model created by the Linear SVM performed slightly better than the LR and the RF. Interestingly, the BoW functions have an impact on the precision cards obtained from our results, producing more conservative rating models. In terms of the results of the recall, we can see that the Logistic Regression, which uses only pocket embedding features, was the model with the best results; perhaps, when precision is taken into account, the same conclusions provided in Table 5.4, the best model under the F1 score was the Linear SVM, with a score of 0.85. It is worth noting that the combination of Bag-of-Words and-of-Words-Score was the one with the 100-of-Words-of-Combination.

sections.heading: 5.2.1.3 Final Remarks
sections.text: The experiment described above examines an approach to supervised learning using training examples of a series of manually annotated tweets extracted from the entire dataset with the support of a term-based regular expression. The general methodology addresses the problem of constructing a fine-grained Twitter training set for the travel area, as well as the automatic identification of travel-related tweets from a large corpus. We combined different word representations to check whether our classification model could learn relationships between words at both the syntactic and semantic levels. After using standard techniques such as bag-of-words and bag-of-embedients, we combined them and obtained results that showed that these different sets of features can complement each other in terms of Portuguese-speaking tweets. Transportation is constantly evolving and new services are emerging that make it difficult to identify related tweets.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 New York City
sections.text: Similar to the experiment on Portuguese-language travel-related classification of tweets, we developed a model for distinguishing between English-language travel-related tweets. However, the construction of training and testing kits in this experiment follows a different approach. While we explored a semi-automatic approach in the experiment in Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo, and tweets were formed almost instantaneously as a group, we had to adopt a two-phase approach here due to the polysemic level of English travel terms. Unlike the experiment in Brazilian cities, tweets were collected from New York City over a two-month period, between March 12 and May 12, 2017.

sections.heading: 5.2.2.1 Training and Test Datasets
sections.text: In the Portuguese dictionary, travel-related terms have no more than one meaning. For example, "caminhar" or even "comboio" has only one meaning. In terms of the English dictionary, travel-related tweets can have more than one meaning, as some of them have a high degree of polysemy. Terms such as "walk" can be used to describe the action of walking or, for example, the action of walking. On the other hand, the term "train" can be used to describe the means of transport train or some type of behavior through practice and instruction. The polysemy level of such terms has been taken into account while the construction process of our training set of tweets has been taken into account for the travel-related English classification model. In the first stage of the construction process, we used the same strategy of Portuguese training. By supporting a semi-automatic labeling technique using a regular printout, we find that the next step in the construction process is a manual verification of a manual tweeting followed by a manual tweeting that is almost all related to each other, the total of which is 686.

sections.heading: 5.2.2.2 Preliminary Results
sections.text: Due to the painstaking and time consuming efforts that have been made in the construction of the training set, we have decided to adopt a different approach in the training phase of our model classification model. To improve the differences between tweets whose terms have a high degree of polysemy, the model was performed using a k-fold cross-validation technique with 10 iterations for all groups of features: bag-of-words and bag-of-embeddings features and bag-of-embeddings features and both combined. Results showed good performance for all models in terms of the selected evaluation metrics. The best model in this experiment was the Logistic Regression classifier trained with bag-of-words and bag-of-embeddings features, which has an F1 score of 0.98324.The fact that all models performed incredibly well, in certain models using the features group of BoW and BoW + BoE raise to us some questions and doubt about the robustness of the training process used, we have achieved the same results by experimenting in Brazilian cities, first, over the Brazilian cities.

sections.heading: 5.2.3 Concluding Remarks
sections.text: The main goal of this experiment was to develop a travel-related tweet classifier that uses word embeddings trained with geo-localized English-language tweets. Similar to the Portuguese classification, we tried to build our model using a combined approach based on word embeddings and word embeddings, but the results showed signs of dependence on word embeddings, which is undesirable given real scenarios and many changes within short periods of time. On the other hand, the near-perfect results led to doubts about the existence of over-embeddings, and so a leave-one-groupout strategy was applied to test the robustness of features. There, we excluded one of the travel mode classes, which resulted in models using word embeddings not being able to maintain the previously demonstrated performance. Parallel to the approach based on word-embeddings, the models that used lintime-embeddings were based on SVO word-embeddings, which resulted in SVO having the consistency and consistency of word-based models.

sections.heading: 5.3 Summary
sections.text: This chapter is intended to report on the experiments carried out during the period of this dissertation in order to help and validate the implementation of the various modules designed in our framework architecture. Firstly, thematic modeling techniques were applied among Portuguese-language tweets for two different megacities, Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo, to extract information that can allow interesting characterizations in different regions / zones of cities in terms of temporal and geographical distributions. Although there are enormous limitations on the labeling of each topic, the results show promising contributions and information for the smart cities, which up to this point allows possible identification of the hottest topics over time.The location of these topics is difficult because, as mentioned in Section 4.1, the design of a geographical distribution is difficult because the majority of the tweets do not have exact location and information for the smart cities. In the future, this problem will have to be addressed in order to enable the possible recognition of geographical issues.

sections.heading: 6.4 Future Work . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 68
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 6.1 Final Remarks
sections.text: This work addresses the issue of extracting meaningful and actionable knowledge of user-generated content within smart cities and smart transport systems. We have developed and developed a framework for capturing, processing and cleansing geo-localized tweets. Specifically, it provides functionality for capturing tweets in parallel from multiple predefined delimitation fields (cities or regions), including filtering non-compliance tweets, word preprocessing for Portuguese and English, theme modeling and transport-specific text classifiers, as well as aggregation and data visualization. The Twitter Streaming API has three different heuristics for collecting tweets: term-based retrievals that follow user activity and collect all tweets within a specific framework. The final stakeholders of our framework are cities and provide content and geographical analysis, we opt for the sites that define tweets more respectfully, but we have found that several of the tweets do not retrieve.

sections.heading: 6.2 Contributions
sections.text: At the end of this dissertation, we will summarize the contributions we achieve in three main dimensions: • Technical contributions We have designed and developed an open source framework implemented in the Python programming language, using the Tweepy library to capture geo-localized tweets. Our implementation enables the capture of multiple and parallel bouncing boxes (cities or regions) and complies with the usage limitations of the Twitter Streaming API. We have chosen to use a no-SQL database (MongoDB) as data storage software that provides flexibility, scalability, and adaptability to the framework. We also rely on Python's LDA library for theme modeling, Gensim library to train paragraph2vec embedding from geo-localized tweets, and Sckit-learn to train test classifiers. The framework also provides flexible aggregations and close-to-range visualization of multiple fragment cities to be used in multiple-geographic regions.

sections.heading: 6.3 Publications
sections.text: During the period of this dissertation, we published three different scientific papers to share the methods and results of our experiments. • João Pereira, Arian Pasquali, Pedro Saleiro and Rosaldo J. F. Rossetti. Transportation in Social Media: an automatic classifier for travel-related tweets. In Portuguese Conferenceon Artificial Intelligence (EPIA), 2017. In Press [PPSR17]. • João Pereira, Arian Pasquali, Pedro Saleiro, Rosaldo J. F. Rossetti and Javier Sanchez Medina. Classifying Travel-related Tweets Using Word Embeddings. In IEEE 20th In-ternational Conference on Intelligent Transportation Systems (IEEE ITSC), 2017. Under review. • João Pereira, Arian Pasquali, Pedro Saleiro, Rosaldo J. F. Rossetti and Nélio Cacho. Characterizing Geo-located Tweets in Brazilian Megacities. In The Third International SmartCities (Review, 2017).

sections.heading: 6.4 Future Work
sections.text: This year, it is closer than ever before in the history of the country.

references.title: Social media analytics and intelligence
author: Daniel Zeng
Hsinchun Chen
Robert Lusch
Shu-Hsing Li

metadata.abstractText: With the rise of Social Media, people obtain and share information almost instantly on a 24/7 basis. Many research areas have tried to gain valuable insights from these large volumes of freely available user generated content. The research areas of intelligent transportation systems and smart cities are no exception. However, extracting meaningful and actionable knowledge from user generated content is a complex endeavor. First, each social media service has its own data collection specificities and constraints, second the volume of messages/posts produced can be overwhelming for automatic processing and mining, and last but not the least, social media texts are usually short, informal, with a lot of abbreviations, jargon, slang and idioms. In this thesis, we try to tackle some of the aforementioned challenges with the goal of extracting knowledge from social media streams that might be useful in the context of intelligent transportation systems and smart cities. We designed and developed a framework for collection, processing and mining of geo-located Tweets. More specifically, it provides functionalities for parallel collection of geo-located tweets from multiple pre-defined bounding boxes (cities or regions), including filtering of non complying tweets, text pre-processing for Portuguese and English language, topic modeling, and transportation-specific text classifiers, as well as, aggregation and data visualization. We performed an extensive exploratory data analysis of geo-located tweets in 5 different cities: Rio de Janeiro, São Paulo, New York City, London and Melbourne, comprising a total of more than 43 millions tweets in a period of 3 months. Furthermore, we performed a large scale topic modelling comparison between Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo. As far as we know this is the largest scale content analysis of geo-located tweets from Brazil. Interestingly, most of the topics are shared between both cities which despite being in the same country are considered very different regarding population, economy and lifestyle. We take advantage of recent developments in word embeddings and train such representations from the collections of geo-located tweets. We then use a combination of bag-of-embeddings and traditional bag-of-words to train travel-related classifiers in both Portuguese and English to filter travel-related content from non-related. We created specific gold-standard data to perform empirical evaluation of the resulting classifiers. Results are in line with research work in other application areas by showing the robustness of using word embeddings to learn word similarities that bag-of-words is not able to capture. The source code and resources developed in this dissertation will be publicly available to foster further developments by the research community in smart cities and intelligent transportation systems.
